title: Luke Jones (rugby union)
text:
Luke Jones (born 2 April 1991) is a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer. His regular playing position is either <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%235.%20lock">lock</a> or <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%236.%20flank">flanker</a>. He represents <a href="Racing%2092">Racing 92</a> in the French <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a> competition, having previously played for the <a href="Melbourne%20Rebels">Melbourne Rebels</a> and the <a href="Western%20Force">Western Force</a> in <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a>.
Playing history.
Jones represented the <a href="Australian%20Schoolboys%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australian Schoolboys</a> in both 2008 and 2009. He was a Schoolboys' captain in 2009, and named to play in a test against <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20schoolboy%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand</a> in <a href="Ballymore%20Stadium">Brisbane</a>. He also captained NSW Schools in 2009 at the Australian National Championships. He was selected to tour the UK with the Australian Schoolboys in late 2009, and selected again to play <a href="Ireland%20national%20schoolboy%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland</a>. Jones then returned to Australia to train with the <a href="Western%20Force">Western Force</a> in Perth. He had signed with the Force while at <a href="St%20Pius%20X%20College%2C%20Sydney">St Pius X College</a> in Sydney, to become the first forward in Australian rugby to sign a full-time professional contract while still at school.
Jones had a busy 2010. He made his <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> debut in <a href="Westpac%20Stadium">Wellington</a> against the <a href="Hurricanes%20%28rugby%20union%29">Hurricanes</a>; he hadn't yet turned 19 when he came off the bench to help Force captain <a href="Nathan%20Sharpe">Nathan Sharpe</a> lock the scrum in the <a href="2010%20Super%2014%20season">competition's</a> second round. At the <a href="2010%20IRB%20Junior%20World%20Championship">2010 JWC</a> in Argentina he scored one of Australia's nine tries to help the <a href="Australia%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> wallop Scotland 58–13 in a pool match. And he helped <a href="Sydney%20Uni%20Football%20Club">Sydney Uni</a> win its club competition.
In March 2010 it was announced Jones would leave the Force to transfer to the <a href="Melbourne%20Rebels">Melbourne Rebels</a> ready for the <a href="2011%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2011 Super Rugby season</a>. In May 2011 he made his Rebels debut against the <a href="Cheetahs%20%28rugby%20union%29">Cheetahs</a> in <a href="Bloemfontein">South Africa</a>. In June he received the 'Rebel Rising Player of the Year' award, and competed for Australia in the <a href="2011%20IRB%20Junior%20World%20Championship">JWC</a> in Italy. His JWC teammates included <a href="St%20Pius%20X%20College%2C%20Sydney">SPX</a> alumni and flanker <a href="Michael%20Hooper%20%28rugby%20union%29">Michael Hooper</a> (<a href="Brumbies">Brumbies</a> from 2010), and prop <a href="Paul%20Alo-Emile">Paul Alo-Emile</a> (Rebels from 2012).
Jones began his <a href="2012%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2012 Super Rugby season</a> at number 6 (blindside flanker) in the Rebels season opener against the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Waratahs">Waratahs</a>. He continued with the Rebels in <a href="2013%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2013</a> and <a href="2014%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2014</a>.
In 2013, Jones re-signed with the Rebels until the end of the 2016 <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> season.
On 12 May 2020, Jones return to France to join <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a> rivals <a href="Racing%2092">Racing 92</a> ahead of the 2020-21 season.
